linkTarget.anchoringText: Bahrain Field is an asymmetrical anticline trending in the north-south direction. The field comprises 22 multi-stack carbonate and sandstone reservoirs (Figure 1) with the hydrocarbon content varying from tarry oil in the shallow Aruma to dry gas in the deeper Khuff reservoirs. The geology of the field is complex with a large number of faults occurring in the Wasia group formations, which contain the major oil reservoir of the Bahrain field, the Mauddud reservoir which is the subject of this paper.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Stratigraphic column for the Awali field, Bahrain

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphic column for the Awali field, Bahrain

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mauddud is a Middle Cretaceous carbonate deposited on a shallow-to-open marine carbonate ramp that is today’s Arabian shelf. Numerous low-relief faults juxtapose Mauddud against overlying Wara and underlying Nahr-Umr, part of the Bahrain zone reservoirs (Figure 1). The average porosity, permeability and thickness are 27%, 25 md and 110’ respectively (Figure 2). The Mauddud reservoir is subdivided into the upper Mauddud A (also called Ba) and lower Mauddud B (also called Bb) intervals.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Bahrain reservoirs type log

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bahrain reservoirs type log

linkTarget.anchoringText: Crestal gas injection for pressure maintenance has been used in the central area of the Mauddud reservoir since 1938. Open-hole logs have been used to track the expansion of the gas cap and Oil-Cater Contact (OWC) over several decades. The current gas caps in Mauddud A, Mauddud B and OWC are shown in Figure 3. Owing to structural extent and differing Petrophysical characteristics, the gas cap has mainly expanded in the Mauddud A and to a smaller extent in Mauddud B. Since Mauddud A gas cap is now approaching the top of the oil-water transition zone, gas production has increased beyond the capacity of the surface gas handling equipment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Top Mauddud structure map with gas cap and OWC

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top Mauddud structure map with gas cap and OWC

linkTarget.anchoringText: For reservoir analysis, Mauddud has historically been divided into areas based on injection, production and facilities. Recently, the areas have been re-designated (Figure 4) based on gas streamlines generated by a dynamic reservoir model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Gas injection streamlines in old defined Mauddud areas vs. the new areas.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas injection streamlines in old defined Mauddud areas vs. the new areas.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows the current gas handling flow diagram. Injection gas for Mauddud (~500 mmscfd) and other reservoirs is sourced from Khuff and Tatweer compressors. The produced gas (~650 mmscfd) is partly sent to compressors (~330 mmscfpd) for Mauddud reinjection and the balance (~300 mmscfd) along with the BAPCO refinery off-gas goes to BANAGAS, Bahrain National Gas Company plant to recover Propane, Butane and Naphtha.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Khuff gas injection schematic with associated gas production and re-injection systems

formatted-caption.caption-text: Khuff gas injection schematic with associated gas production and re-injection systems

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir simulation studies recommended an increase in gas injection to increase oil production. This could achieved by increasing gas handling capacities so to re-inject the excess gas that cannot be processed by BANAGAS plant. Four phases of compression have been implemented (Figure 6):

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Compressor capacity over phases

formatted-caption.caption-text: Compressor capacity over phases

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7a illustrates the HI concept for a well A-0182 with respect to the oil production performance of a group of wells (average Mauddud production in this case). It shows that the well was overperforming (oil HI > 0) compared to average Mauddud wells when it was completed in 1958. Later, after year 2000, its performance deteriorated as flagged by a negative HI.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7a
image-wrap.caption: Definition of oil Heterogeneity Index and cumulative Heterogeneity Index for a well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Definition of oil Heterogeneity Index and cumulative Heterogeneity Index for a well

linkTarget.anchoringText: The bottom plot in Figure 7a demonstrates the HI and cumHI for oil production at a reference time when the well was completed in year 1958. The oil cumHI shows an increasing trend till year 2011 after which it started decreasing due to water encroachment or gas breakthrough. Figure 7b on the other hand, shows oil, water and gas HI for the same well in Figure 7a. It explains the decreasing trend in oil HI after the year 2000 where the water HI increased due to water encroachment with low gas HI.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7b
image-wrap.caption: Illustration of oil, water and gas Heterogeneity Index for a specific well versus group of wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Illustration of oil, water and gas Heterogeneity Index for a specific well versus group of wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Prior to 2011, the pressure maps showed that there were low-pressure areas in the north (areas A&H) and the south (areas D&E) (Figure 8). These areas were also referred to as areas 1-6 and 4-5 respectively in the older designation (Figure 4). Figure 8 also shows that CumHI water was high in those areas as a results of water influx due to low pressure regions.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: 2011 and 2013 Pressure maps with 2011 water HI map for Mauddud reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: 2011 and 2013 Pressure maps with 2011 water HI map for Mauddud reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 maps oil, water and gas cumHI taking 2011 as a reference time for the integration. After 2 years of gas injection, the areas with new injectors showed trends of positive oil CumHI associated with increase in gas CumHI indicating the incremental oil response from increased gas injection. Additionally, water CumHI decreased substantially in those areas. Another observation from this study was the trends of oil and gas cumHI indicated gas streamlines in NW-SE direction which aligns with the understanding of the major faults and fracture networks in the Mauddud reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Post-Appraisal of 2011 Phase-1 Compression: Cum HI Gas vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011{Cum HI Oil >0}

formatted-caption.caption-text: Post-Appraisal of 2011 Phase-1 Compression: Cum HI Gas vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 shows oil productivity increased post Phase-1 compression in 2011. It also shows that the VRR increased after adding the two injectors A-0858 and A-0635 in the areas A&H. The average oil productivity increased from 40 bopd in 2010 to more than 100 bopd in 2016. Figures-11a&b show gas/oil and water/oil cross plots of cumHI. Every curve represents a well’s trajectory of its historical CumHI gas/water vs cumHI oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Post-Appraisal of 2011 Phase-1 Compression: Cum HI for Gas vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

formatted-caption.caption-text: Post-Appraisal of 2011 Phase-1 Compression: Cum HI for Gas vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures-11a&b show gas/oil and water/oil cross plots of cumHI. Every curve represents a well’s trajectory of its historical CumHI gas/water vs cumHI oil. These plots identify good and poor performers with respect to water injection and gas injection. The top right quadrant of cumHI gas vs. cumHI oil plot in Figure 11a show the good oil producers which respond well to gas injection (green wells). The blue set shows the poor performers where the wells are circulating the injected gas and need to be controlled or worked over. Figure 11b, cumHI for water versus cumHI for oil shows most of high water cut wells (blue set) are producing with low oil productivity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11a
image-wrap.caption: Cross-plot Cum HI for Gas vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross-plot Cum HI for Gas vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures-11a&b show gas/oil and water/oil cross plots of cumHI. Every curve represents a well’s trajectory of its historical CumHI gas/water vs cumHI oil. These plots identify good and poor performers with respect to water injection and gas injection. The top right quadrant of cumHI gas vs. cumHI oil plot in Figure 11a show the good oil producers which respond well to gas injection (green wells). The blue set shows the poor performers where the wells are circulating the injected gas and need to be controlled or worked over. Figure 11b, cumHI for water versus cumHI for oil shows most of high water cut wells (blue set) are producing with low oil productivity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11b
image-wrap.caption: Cross-plot Cum HI for Water vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross-plot Cum HI for Water vs. Cum HI Oil after 2011

linkTarget.anchoringText: A typical procedure of these workovers is to perforate at the Ba/Bb interface and squeeze off all the perforations, and then open a new set of perforations in Bb and Cab reservoirs. The GOR after the workovers often drops by more than an order of magnitude (eg. 70 mscf/stb to 1 mscf/stb) which brings them below the marginal GOR limit and become producible. Shown in Figure 12 is a good example of what can be achieved with an effective gas shut-off workover.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: A successful gas shut-off example

formatted-caption.caption-text: A successful gas shut-off example

linkTarget.anchoringText: Cement Bond Logs (CBLs) have also been run on these jobs to evaluate the bond before and after the workover. Some of these jobs require multiple cement squeezes in order to get a good bond as seen in Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Pre and post workover CBL

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pre and post workover CBL

linkTarget.anchoringText: As seen in Figure 14, workovers were done in 2015 (top graph) with very high success rate. The graph is for all the wells which were shut-in and worked over in the year 2015. As can be seen, most of the oil production has been restored to the pre shut-in level with a significant reduction in gas and water production. The 2016 workover program had fewer wells and resulted with only half of them as successful workovers. Reasons of low success rate in 2016 are still under evaluation but are most likely due to the pumping pressure during the acid-wash treatment where it was seen that fracturing pressure was exceeded during stimulation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Gas shut-off workover results

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas shut-off workover results

linkTarget.anchoringText: The locations of Phases 1 & 2 are illustrated in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Mauddud location map highlighting Phases 1 and 2

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mauddud location map highlighting Phases 1 and 2

linkTarget.anchoringText: Phase 1 started on 29th September 2015 and covered areas A and H to the north (Figure-16) where 5 wells injecting 80 mmscfd of Khuff gas were shut-in. As shown in Figure-17, no incremental decline was observed in the first 2 months of the trial. The area exhibited a drop of around 500 bopd in the 3rd month with an increase in reservoir oil decline rate associated with a decline in gas production and an increase in water cut. The reduction in gas production from the affected area also resulted in opening shut-in wells in other areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: VRR trial Phase 1 map with injectors and producers (since 29th Sept 2015)

formatted-caption.caption-text: VRR trial Phase 1 map with injectors and producers (since 29th Sept 2015)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Phase 1 started on 29th September 2015 and covered areas A and H to the north (Figure-16) where 5 wells injecting 80 mmscfd of Khuff gas were shut-in. As shown in Figure-17, no incremental decline was observed in the first 2 months of the trial. The area exhibited a drop of around 500 bopd in the 3rd month with an increase in reservoir oil decline rate associated with a decline in gas production and an increase in water cut. The reduction in gas production from the affected area also resulted in opening shut-in wells in other areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: VRR trial Phase 1 production profile (since 29th Sept 2015)

formatted-caption.caption-text: VRR trial Phase 1 production profile (since 29th Sept 2015)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Figure 18 shows the bottom hole pressure (BHP) collected at different times in the area. The results indicate higher drop in the east (area A) and the west (area H) compared to the central area. These two pressure sinks identified were further away from the gas injectors and towards the flank of the Mauddud reservoir. As a consequence of this trial, two new gas injector locations have been proposed in these areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: VRR trial Phase 1 pressure maps

formatted-caption.caption-text: VRR trial Phase 1 pressure maps

linkTarget.anchoringText: Completion of the first phase has yielded encouraging results to continue with the VRR program. The second phase started on 18th February 2016 included areas D and E to the south (Figure 19) where 4 injectors were shut-in.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: VRR trial Phase 2 area (since 18th Feb 2016)

formatted-caption.caption-text: VRR trial Phase 2 area (since 18th Feb 2016)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil drop in this area was seen within the 2nd month of the trial, as shown in Figure 20. The wells closest to injectors A-0645 and A-0557 showed a drop in gross liquid and gas production soon after the injectors were shut-in. An example of the drop is seen in Figure 21 where the gas and oil decreased and water cut increased, leading to a drop in well head pressure. In this example, the well manifold pressure is also monitored to ensure that no surface facility issue is causing the change in well behavior.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: VRR trial Phase 2 production profile (since 18th Feb 2016)

formatted-caption.caption-text: VRR trial Phase 2 production profile (since 18th Feb 2016)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil drop in this area was seen within the 2nd month of the trial, as shown in Figure 20. The wells closest to injectors A-0645 and A-0557 showed a drop in gross liquid and gas production soon after the injectors were shut-in. An example of the drop is seen in Figure 21 where the gas and oil decreased and water cut increased, leading to a drop in well head pressure. In this example, the well manifold pressure is also monitored to ensure that no surface facility issue is causing the change in well behavior.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: well A-0429 production behavior

formatted-caption.caption-text: well A-0429 production behavior

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pressure surveys in phase 2 were done in the same manner as phase 1. Figure-22 shows the pressure maps at different times in the area. The results indicated higher drop in the east (area E) compared to the west (area D), which indicates that the injection in the west was strongly supporting the east due to the areal pressure gradient between the two areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: VRR trial Phase 2 pressure maps

formatted-caption.caption-text: VRR trial Phase 2 pressure maps
